Kiara Advani’s sizzling pictures from an old photoshoot will drive away your lockdown blues

Kiara Advani has very successfully made her mark in Bollywood with her choices of films and performances. She is also quite active on social media where she commands a huge fan following. She is often seen sharing pictures and videos of herself with her followers and they just cannot have enough of the pretty actress. We recently got our hands on some sizzling throwback picture of Kiara from an old magazine photoshoot and it is sure to beat your lockdown blues. Check out the photos here:In the pictures, Kiara is seen looking drop-dead gorgeous in a shimmery silver attire. Her coloured hair and matching accessories compliment her overall stunning look. The actress had dolled up for a photoshoot for Hello! Magazine and was styled by none other than Bollywood’s ace designer Manish Malhotra. On the work front, she has some pretty interesting projects in her kitty which includes, ‘Bhool Bhulaiyaa 2’ where she will be seen sharing the screen space with none other than Kartik Aaryan. This will be the first time that Kartik and Kiara will be seen together on screen. She will also be seen in ‘Laxmmi Bomb’ where she will be seen starring opposite Akshay Kumar. Kiara will also star opposite Sidharth Malhotra in ‘Shershaah’. Apart from her work life, she is mostly hitting the headlines for her love affair with Sidharth Malhotra. Although they are yet to come out in open about it, their social media PDA, dinner dates and outings speak volume about their love affair.

Demi Lovato Stuns In Sultry Pool Pics And Her Man Is Loving It!

Demi Lovato is taking advantage of the free time she has because of the quarantine orders to learn new skills including how to use the self timer on her phone and take steamy pool pics! She shared a couple of snaps on her Instagram and it’s safe to say that her boyfriend, Max Ehrich was impressed and so were her followers! Demi looked stunning and sultry with no makeup on and wearing a strapless one piece swimsuit while she posed by the pool. In the caption, she jokingly wrote: ‘Swipe to see how I discovered the self-timer feature for taking pics. @angelokritikos [her photographer] – you in trouble boo boo 😝🌴.’ The photographer was quick to respond, playing along: ‘BRING IT ON BOO 🔥🔥🔥🔥🔥🔥🔥🔥🔥🔥 😍😍😍😍.’ In the meantime, her boyfriend also took to the comment section to show her some love by simply leaving a heart-eyes emoji! Fellow celebs gushed over Demi as well, including Ashley Graham and JoJo. Demi and her new man haven’t been together for very long but they already seem like they have a great bond. One insider dished that they really love spending time together so the joint quarantine is no problem. Speaking of relationships, during an interview on the I Weigh podcast with actress Jameela Jamil, Demi revealed that she is not in touch with any of her ex boyfriends. ‘I kind of used to have this mentality that if I had a negative experience with somebody, I needed to mend it or needed to make things right. The fact of the matter is that I’m not really friends with any of my exes because I had to realize that that was not healthy either.’ ‘Now that I have been able to fully let go of people, that is another thing I had to learn when it comes to cutting the toxic people out of your life – if they are an ex, it is for a reason,’ she dished.

Top fives: Struggling to get motivated? YouTube is surprisingly helpful

Weighted average IN: 1.720587750415579

Top fives: Struggling to get motivated? YouTube is surprisingly helpful

Now is the perfect time to catch up on the best books, films, television shows and podcasts you might have missed. Here are five YouTube channels that are worth a look, and five music videos to motivate you to meet your workout goals. The School of Life Beautifully-produced clips containing essential wisdom and advice for these tough times. Sam HarrisGuided meditations (without the woo-woo) from the best-selling author and philosopher. Jansen’s DIYLearn how to make a room feel bigger and master the art of “lazy cleaning”. That Mitchell & Mack CollectionNeed a laugh? These clips from British comedy show Would I Lie To You? will do the trick. HASfitTerrific instructional exercise videos to help you stay healthy at home. Shake it Off – Taylor Swift At 160 beats per minute, this track is a perfect song to run on the treadmill to while using Taylor’s fantastic physique as your #fitspo. Single Ladies – Beyonce With little else to do in isolation, why not use the opportunity to learn the full choreography to Beyonce’s 2008 hit so you are performance ready when the clubs reopen. Call on Me – Eryk Prydz If full choreography isn’t for you, Call on Me offers 2.51 minute gym class that you can just watch on repeat until you feel fit. Blinding Lights – The Weeknd Bypass the official music video and find the complication of Tik Tok dances to craft the perfect workout to this '80s-like banger. Brave – Sara Bareilles This song should probably be our isolation anthem, but if you’re pushing through that 80th crunch, let Sara inspire you to get to 100.

3 May 20:00 • The Age • https://www.theage.com.au/culture/music/top-fives-struggling-to-get-motivated-youtube-is-surprisingly-helpful-20200415-p54k6m.html?ref=rss&utm_medium=rss&utm_source=rss_feed
Rating: 2.20

International Jazz Day review: The art of getting distant and personal

3 May 14:02 • 3 articles
Weight: 1.80
Importance: 1.80
Age penalty: 1.00
Best date: 3 May 14:02
Average US: 3.733333333333333
Weighted average US: 3.1681237569867884
Average GB: 0.0
Weighted average GB: 0.0
Average IN: 1.8333333333333333
Weighted average IN: 1.720587750415579

International Jazz Day review: The art of getting distant and personal

MUSIC INTERNATIONAL JAZZ DAY LIVE STREAM ★★★★ April 30 Reviewed by JOHN SHAND International Jazz Day (April 30) has celebrated jazz's role in helping unite people the world over since 2011. This year, when the host nation was to have been South Africa, it was, instead, another reminder of a community splintered into an epidemic of isolation. But, thanks to a commendable collaboration between the Sydney Improvised Music Association and Johnston St Jazz, a 140-minute mini-festival occurred via two livestreams and one pre-recorded concert. If the bands chosen could have more thoroughly reflected the sheer diversity of what passes for jazz, they were all able to bridge the livestream remoteness. Over half the time was allotted to the final act, the Jeremy Rose Quartet, with Rose having become a composer of note, especially via his major work, Iron in the Blood, which was included in the distant memory that is this year's Sydney Festival. Although Rose's work for his quartet stays much closer to the jazz mainstream than does Iron in the Blood, he still finds fresh compositional ideas with which to prod the idiom and to stimulate improvising options. In the piano solo on the meditative Religion, for instance, Steve Barry could deploy all his capacity to tease, suspend or subvert the listener's expectations. The dark, edgy and aptly named Precipice began with solo bass from Noel Mason, which beckoned Rose's bass clarinet, the instrument on which he has developed his most distinctive voice and widest palette of colours. On the brilliantly evocative Aktau, Mason's bass seemed to convey the enormity of Kazakhstan's White Mountains, Rose's tenor the altitude, Barry's piano the crystalline air, and Alex Hirlian's drums the excitement. The Mezza/Ginsburg Ensemble, a collaboration co-led by Italian pianist Vittorio Mezza and Australian pianist Mark Ginsburg (with bassist Karl Dunnicliff and drummer Tim Firth) was filmed at last year's Sydney Con International Jazz Festival, and suddenly it was novel to see an audience on hand! Dunnicliff produced notably fine solos on two of Ginsburg's pieces: the gentle For You and Common Purpose, the latter made lush with the addition of a substantial choir. Vocalist Kate Wadey, pianist Andrew Scott and bassist Sam Dobson opened the celebration and, while Wadey's breathy, unforced singing was especially effective on I've Got a Crush on You, with the piano dancing behind her, the rest of the performance proved more uneven.

3 May 14:02 • The Age • https://www.theage.com.au/culture/music/international-jazz-day-review-the-art-of-getting-distant-and-personal-20200501-p54owp.html?ref=rss&utm_medium=rss&utm_source=rss_feed
Rating: 2.20
International Jazz Day review: The art of getting distant and personal

MUSIC INTERNATIONAL JAZZ DAY LIVE STREAM ★★★★ April 30 Reviewed by JOHN SHAND International Jazz Day (April 30) has celebrated jazz's role in helping unite people the world over since 2011. This year, when the host nation was to have been South Africa, it was, instead, another reminder of a community splintered into an epidemic of isolation. But, thanks to a commendable collaboration between the Sydney Improvised Music Association and Johnston St Jazz, a 140-minute mini-festival occurred via two livestreams and one pre-recorded concert. Over half the time was allotted to the final act, the Jeremy Rose Quartet, with Rose having become a composer of note, especially via his major work, Iron in the Blood, which was included in the distant memory that is this year's Sydney Festival. Vocalist Kate Wadey, pianist Andrew Scott and bassist Sam Dobson opened the celebration and, while Wadey's breathy, unforced singing was especially effective on I've Got a Crush on You, with the piano dancing behind her, the rest of the performance proved more uneven.

Rating: 0.55
Entertainment
There's nothing like a dame for easing the shutdown blues

3 May 14:00 • 3 articles
Weight: 1.80
Importance: 1.80
Age penalty: 1.00
Best date: 3 May 14:00
Average US: 3.733333333333333
Weighted average US: 3.1681237569867884
Average GB: 0.0
Weighted average GB: 0.0
Average IN: 1.8333333333333333
Weighted average IN: 1.720587750415579

There's nothing like a dame for easing the shutdown blues

Opera Australia has launched a free online streaming service featuring interviews and recordings of past productions, with a particular emphasis on the company’s vast collection of performances by the legendary Dame Joan Sutherland. OATV launches today with a recording of 2012’s inaugural opera on Sydney Harbour performance of La Traviata plus a 1988 production of The Merry Widow with Sutherland as the eponymous Hanna Glawari. Artistic director Lyndon Terracini said the project had been in the works for some time but that the virus-driven shutdown had accelerated development. “Hopefully, people will feel it has a bit more substance than what you usually see online,” he said. Terracini was personally devastated when the shutdown was announced. "It was frankly extremely depressing,” he said. “I was a bit down for a few weeks and then I had to figure out what I was going to do so I started doing OATV and working on other projects to keep busy. If I’m not busy I get depressed and that's not good.” Terracini said he felt for all the artists left high and dry by the crisis, particularly singers such as rising star Natalie Aroyan, who managed only two performances as Odabella in Verdi’s Attila and soprano Stacey Alleaume, who was to sing Violetta in La Traviata on the harbour stage this year. But despite the uncertainly about when audiences will be allowed to return to the opera theatre, Terracini insisted Opera Australia continued to plan for the future. "As far as we are concerned, we hope to be up and running before too long but having said that I think we all realise the world is going to be a very different place.” He likened the current situation to that in 2009, when he first took the reins of OA in the aftermath of the global financial crisis. “The company was in a pretty terrible state and we had to do things differently,” he said. “I introduced Handa Opera on Sydney Harbour, the musicals and a different sort of repertoire. Last year and 2018 were unbelievably successful years for the company and were the culmination of 10 years’ work but now we will have to start again. That's all gone. “It’s a depressing and daunting task but that's the way it is. It’s happened and we can’t do anything about that. We will just have to be more creative and think about who and what we are going to be from next year on.” Terracini also dropped his strongest hint yet that this year’s much anticipated La Traviata, which was to have opened on the harbour on March 27, will be shifted to 2021. “Let’s just say I wouldn’t want Stacey [Alleaume] or Con [director Constantine Costi] or any of the other artists who have worked so hard on Traviata for this year not to be given a chance to do it,” he said.

3 May 14:00 • The Age • https://www.theage.com.au/culture/opera/there-s-nothing-like-a-dame-for-easing-the-shutdown-blues-20200502-p54p9v.html?ref=rss&utm_medium=rss&utm_source=rss_feed
Rating: 2.20
There's nothing like a dame for easing the shutdown blues

Opera Australia has launched a free online streaming service featuring interviews and recordings of past productions, with a particular emphasis on the company’s vast collection of performances by the legendary Dame Joan Sutherland. OATV launches today with a recording of 2012’s inaugural opera on Sydney Harbour performance of La Traviata plus a 1988 production of The Merry Widow with Sutherland as the eponymous Hanna Glawari. Artistic director Lyndon Terracini said the project had been in the works for some time but that the virus-driven shutdown had accelerated development. “Hopefully, people will feel it has a bit more substance than what you usually see online,” he said. Terracini was personally devastated when the shutdown was announced. "It was frankly extremely depressing,” he said. “I was a bit down for a few weeks and then I had to figure out what I was going to do so I started doing OATV and working on other projects to keep busy. If I’m not busy I get depressed and that's not good.” Terracini said he felt for all the artists left high and dry by the crisis, particularly singers such as rising star Natalie Aroyan, who managed only two performances as Odabella in Verdi’s Attila and soprano Stacey Alleaume, who was to sing Violetta in La Traviata on the harbour stage this year. But despite the uncertainly about when audiences will be allowed to return to the opera theatre, Terracini insisted Opera Australia continued to plan for the future. "As far as we are concerned, we hope to be up and running before too long but having said that I think we all realise the world is going to be a very different place.” He likened the current situation to that in 2009, when he first took the reins of OA in the aftermath of the global financial crisis. “The company was in a pretty terrible state and we had to do things differently,” he said. “I introduced Handa Opera on Sydney Harbour, the musicals and a different sort of repertoire. Last year and 2018 were unbelievably successful years for the company and were the culmination of 10 years’ work but now we will have to start again. That's all gone. “It’s a depressing and daunting task but that's the way it is. It’s happened and we can’t do anything about that. We will just have to be more creative and think about who and what we are going to be from next year on.” Terracini also dropped his strongest hint yet that this year’s much anticipated La Traviata, which was to have opened on the harbour on March 27, will be shifted to 2021. “Let’s just say I wouldn’t want Stacey [Alleaume] or Con [director Constantine Costi] or any of the other artists who have worked so hard on Traviata for this year not to be given a chance to do it,” he said.

3 May 14:00 • Brisbane Times • https://www.brisbanetimes.com.au/culture/opera/there-s-nothing-like-a-dame-for-easing-the-shutdown-blues-20200502-p54p9v.html?ref=rss&utm_medium=rss&utm_source=rss_feed
Rating: 0.86
There's nothing like a dame for easing the shutdown blues

Opera Australia has launched a free online streaming service featuring interviews and recordings of past productions, with a particular emphasis on the company’s vast collection of performances by the legendary Dame Joan Sutherland. OATV launches today with a recording of 2012’s inaugural opera on Sydney Harbour performance of La Traviata plus a 1988 production of The Merry Widow with Sutherland as the eponymous Hanna Glawari. Artistic director Lyndon Terracini said the project had been in the works for some time but that the virus-driven shutdown had accelerated development. “Hopefully, people will feel it has a bit more substance than what you usually see online,” he said. Terracini was personally devastated when the shutdown was announced. "It was frankly extremely depressing,” he said. “I was a bit down for a few weeks and then I had to figure out what I was going to do so I started doing OATV and working on other projects to keep busy. If I’m not busy I get depressed and that's not good.” Terracini said he felt for all the artists left high and dry by the crisis, particularly singers such as rising star Natalie Aroyan, who managed only two performances as Odabella in Verdi’s Attila and soprano Stacey Alleaume, who was to sing Violetta in La Traviata on the harbour stage this year. But despite the uncertainly about when audiences will be allowed to return to the opera theatre, Terracini insisted Opera Australia continued to plan for the future. "As far as we are concerned, we hope to be up and running before too long but having said that I think we all realise the world is going to be a very different place.” He likened the current situation to that in 2009, when he first took the reins of OA in the aftermath of the global financial crisis. “The company was in a pretty terrible state and we had to do things differently,” he said. “I introduced Handa Opera on Sydney Harbour, the musicals and a different sort of repertoire. Last year and 2018 were unbelievably successful years for the company and were the culmination of 10 years’ work but now we will have to start again. That's all gone. “It’s a depressing and daunting task but that's the way it is. It’s happened and we can’t do anything about that. We will just have to be more creative and think about who and what we are going to be from next year on.” Terracini also dropped his strongest hint yet that this year’s much anticipated La Traviata, which was to have opened on the harbour on March 27, will be shifted to 2021. “Let’s just say I wouldn’t want Stacey [Alleaume] or Con [director Constantine Costi] or any of the other artists who have worked so hard on Traviata for this year not to be given a chance to do it,” he said.

3 May 14:00 • WAtoday • https://www.watoday.com.au/culture/opera/there-s-nothing-like-a-dame-for-easing-the-shutdown-blues-20200502-p54p9v.html?ref=rss&utm_medium=rss&utm_source=rss_feed

Holly Willoughby quits TV role and issues poignant statement

3 May 18:14 • 13 articles

Average GB: 22.8
Weighted average GB: 14.50673160111053
Average IN: 6.376923076923077
Weighted average IN: 6.664955810380675

Holly Willoughby quits TV role and issues poignant statement

Holly Willoughby has quit Celebrity Juice, she has announced. The mum-of-three has left her role on the ITV2 show after over a decade. Holly, aged 39, had spent 12 years on the series. She starred alongside the likes of Fearne Cotton and host Keith Lemon. But pal Fearne quit in 2018 - and now Holly, who also serves as This Morning presenter, has joined her in departing. On Instagram, Holly paid tribute to the show in a gushing post. She wrote how she would miss “12 years of fantastic chaos," adding: “I can’t quite believe what we’ve done and how quick that time has gone. “Thank you to you all for watching. We’ve always had the loudest and best audiences…. “It’s never felt like work and always been to me like a night out. “Thank you for all your ingenious ideas and hard work…  All good things must come to an end and nothing lasts forever. “It’s time for me to hand over my team captain seat to some lucky, lucky person.” She said of Lemon: “I remember starting this journey with you and saying ‘I think this might work’. My goodness me it did. “Three friends, you me and  Fearne Cotton … and that is what is at the heart of it, friendship. I love the bones of you Lemon! “Thank you for making me laugh for 12 years… I’ll be back as a guest and just to make sure someone is keeping you in check.”

3 May 18:14 • birminghammail • https://www.birminghammail.co.uk/news/showbiz-tv/holly-willoughby-quits-tv-role-18192434
Rating: 0.34
Holly Willoughby confirms she has quit ITV show after 12 years

Holly Willoughby has quit Celebrity Juice after 12 years on the ITV2 show. The TV presenter, 39, has left her team captain role saying "all good things must come to an end". Her friend Fearne Cotton, 38, quit the long-running series, starring Keith Lemon, 47, in 2018. Holly said she had enjoyed "12 years of fantastic chaos... She posted on Instagram: "I can't quite believe what we've done and how quick that time has gone. "Thank you to you all for watching. We've always had the loudest and best audiences.... "It's never felt like work and always been to me like a night out," the co-host of This Morning said. "Thank you for all your ingenious ideas and hard work... All good things must come to an end and nothing lasts forever. "It's time for me to hand over my team captain seat to some lucky, lucky person." She said of Keith: "I remember starting this journey with you and saying 'I think this might work'. My goodness me it did. "Three friends, you me and Fearne Cotton ... and that is what is at the heart of it, friendship. I love the bones of you Lemon! "Thank you for making me laugh for 12 years... I'll be back as a guest and just to make sure someone is keeping you in check." Keith - real name Leigh Francis - wrote on Twitter: "I've had a lovely time working with you. You are the best! I hope I'm lucky enough to work with you again one day."

3 May 18:57 • Liverpool Echo • https://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/news/showbiz-news/holly-willoughby-confirms-quit-itv-18193172
Rating: 0.83
Jimmy Fallon and His Wife Open Up About 5 Years of Infertility: "Gosh, That Was Just Crazy"

After an adorable introduction for the April 28 at-home edition of The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon, which featured the host's two daughters, Winnie and Franny, Jimmy and his wife, Nancy Juvonen, got candid about having those two very cute kids together. In the "Ask the Fallons" segment of the show (starting around 9:20 in the video above!), the couple were asked, "How did you know you were ready to have kids?" "We were ready when we got married. . . . And you love kids and I love kids," Nancy said. "That was just the plan, it wasn't even [an], 'Are you ready?' It was just, 'Now how are we going to do this?'" The couple have been open about their journey to parenthood, noting that they tried hard to start a family for about five years before turning to surrogacy to have both of their girls. "That was an interesting time," Jimmy said of the years they were trying to conceive. Nancy added: "So that was five years of really, really, really, really, really deciding not to give up, and at a certain point it just had to become almost like a job. Because it's way too emotional to live emotionally through that. So you just keep going and going and going and if you really want something you just make it happen. . . . I think if anyone's out there having the dream [to have kids], do not give up." The couple also touched on the many times they received bad news throughout their journey. Nancy shared that when they got bad news they'd often go away for a weekend to regroup and be together. "We went away a lot," Jimmy said with a laugh. Nancy added, "Some times were easier than others. But then we'd just get right back up." The couple went on to joke a bit about the hoops they had to jump through while trying to conceive. "I had magnets in my underwear," Jimmy said before noting that inevitably having kids through surrogacy is "the best move we ever made" and that they're "so lucky" to have their two beautiful girls who are "the best things ever." Our hearts! Watch the entire video above, especially if you want to hear what they have to say about taking parenting advice!

3 May 17:00 • POPSUGAR Family • https://www.popsugar.com/family/jimmy-fallon-on-having-kids-after-infertility-video-47428771
Rating: 1.91
Holly Willoughby leaves Celebrity Juice after 12 years

Holly Willoughby has confirmed that she has quit Celebrity Juice, saying “all good things must come to an end”. The TV presenter, 39, has left her team captain role after 12 years on the ITV2 show. Her friend Fearne Cotton, 38, quit the long-running series, starring Keith Lemon, 47, in 2018. Willoughby said she had enjoyed “12 years of fantastic chaos… “I can’t quite believe what we’ve done and how quick that time has gone,” she posted on Instagram. “Thank you to you all for watching. We’ve always had the loudest and best audiences…. “It’s never felt like work and always been to me like a night out,” the co-host of This Morning said. “Thank you for all your ingenious ideas and hard work…  All good things must come to an end and nothing lasts forever. “It’s time for me to hand over my team captain seat to some lucky, lucky person.” She said of Lemon: “I remember starting this journey with you and saying ‘I think this might work’. My goodness me it did. “Three friends, you me and  Fearne Cotton … and that is what is at the heart of it, friendship. I love the bones of you Lemon! “Thank you for making me laugh for 12 years… I’ll be back as a guest and just to make sure someone is keeping you in check.” Lemon – real name Leigh Francis – wrote on Twitter: “I’ve had a lovely time working with you. You are the best! I hope I’m lucky enough to work with you again one day.”

3 May 09:46 • Express & Star • https://www.expressandstar.com/entertainment/showbiz/2020/05/03/holly-willoughby-leaves-celebrity-juice-after-12-years/

3 May 09:35 • independent • https://www.independent.ie/entertainment/holly-willoughby-leaves-celebrity-juice-after-12-years-39176962.html
Rating: 1.21
Holly Willoughby confirms she's leaving Celebrity Juice in moving tribute

Holly Willoughby has confirmed the news we have been dreading, that she’s leaving Celebrity Juice after 12 years. The 39-year-old currently appears as a team captain on the show, alongside host Keith Lemon and fellow captain Mel B. And despite rumours circulating that she had quit, the ITV host has now confirmed the sad news on Instagram with a lengthy post. Sharing a series of photos of her time on the show fronted by funnyman Keith, Holly began: ‘Thank you Celebrity Juice for 12 years of fantastic chaos… I can’t quite believe what we’ve done and how quick that time has gone. Thank you to you all for watching..we’ve always had the loudest and best audiences. ‘Also a huge thank you to ITV2 for believing in the show in the first place and for all of your support…Over the years the production team has changed, however to anyone lucky enough to have worked on the show, they will know that we really do have the best time, it’s never felt like work and always been to me like a night out..’ Holly went on to tease who her replacement could be as she continued: ‘Thank you for all your ingenious ideas and hard work… all good things must come to an end and nothing lasts forever… It’s time for me to hand over my team captain seat to some lucky lucky person… whoever that is, know you are about to get one of the best jobs in telly working with one of comedies finest…Keith Lemon. ‘Where to begin… I remember starting this journey with you and saying “I think this might work”… my goodness me it did… three friends, you me and Fearne Cotton and that is what is at the heart of it.. friendship… I love the bones of you Lemon! ‘Thank you for making me laugh for twelve years… I’ll be back as a guest and just to make sure someone is keeping you in check… if I don’t see you through a week or next week or the week after… know you are always in my heart..’ Shortly after Holly’s announcement, Keith shared a hilarious video on social media with the sweetest caption. ‘I’ve had a lovely time working with you. You are the best! ‘I hope I’m lucky enough to work with you again one day. ‘Goodbye Holly Willoughby x’ Holly’s departure comes after close pal Fearne Cotton left Celeb Juice in 2018. Celebrity Juice continues on Thursday, at 10pm, on ITV2. Metro.co.uk has contacted Celebrity Juice for a comment. Got a story? If you’ve got a celebrity story, video or pictures get in touch with the Metro.co.uk entertainment team by emailing us celebtips@metro.co.uk, calling 020 3615 2145 or by visiting our Submit Stuff page – we’d love to hear from you.

Holly Willoughby says ‘all good things come to an end’ as she pays tribute to Keith Lemon after quitting Celebrity Juice

HOLLY Willoughby has paid a heartfelt tribute to Celebrity Juice and its host Keith Lemon after quitting the show. The TV star shared a collection of her best times with Keith on Instagram and wrote how "all good things must come to an end". She said: "Thank you @celebjuiceofficial for 12 years of fantastic chaos... I can’t quite believe what we’ve done and how quick that time has gone. "Thank you to you all for watching.. we’ve always had the loudest and best audiences. "...it’s never felt like work and always been to me like a night out... Thank you for all your ingenious ideas and hard work... all good things must come to an end and nothing lasts forever... Holly told her yet to be named successor they were in for an incredible time. She continued: "It’s time for me to hand over my team captain seat to some lucky lucky person... whoever that is, know you are about to get one of the best jobs in telly working with one of comedies finest... @keithlemon ... "Where to begin... I remember starting this journey with you and saying ‘I think this might work’... my goodness me it did... three friends, you me and @fearnecotton ... and that is what is at the heart of it.. friendship... "I love the bones of you Lemon! Thank you for making me laugh for twelve years... I’ll be back as a guest and just to make sure someone is keeping you in check... if I don’t see you through a week or next week or the week after... know you are always in my heart... ❤️." Last night The Sun exclusively revealed quit the comedy game show after 12 years. The TV presenter, 39, who has three children with her producer husband Dan Baldwin, 45, wants to spend more time with her family. Holly told the ITV2 show’s producers about her decision last week after filming several lockdown editions with host Leigh Francis, 47. Since launching the panel series in 2008 Holly — mum to Harry, ten, Belle, eight, and Chester, five — has become one of the UK’s most successful female TV presenters. She fronts ITV daytime show This Morning, alongside Phillip Schofield, 58, and filled in for Ant McPartlin, 44, two years ago on I’m A Celebrity . . . Get Me Out Of Here. Holly’s decision to quit Celebrity Juice comes after pal and fellow panellist Fearne Cotton, 38, left the series in 2018 to focus on new projects. A TV source said: “Holly has absolutely loved her time on the show — it’s been a huge part of her life, and has really helped to expand her fanbase over the years. “But she feels now is the right time to bow out and wants to free up a bit more of her busy schedule to spend with her family. “She’s still the best of pals with Leigh Francis and will continue to support the series.” Yesterday comic Leigh posted a touching tribute to the star on his alias Keith Lemon’s Instagram page. He wrote: “Love this woman. What an incredible sport. Always willing to get her hands dirty and join in. “One of the boys but all woman. A wicked sense of humour and very easy to look at. “Don’t look into her eyes though, ’cos she can make you do anything. What a lady! King of the ladies! “The queen of the milk beasts! The one and only @hollywilloughby face of an angel but can have the potty mouth of . . . well me I guess. "Super rad! Super nice! My mate! “I salute all your wonderfulness. Massive hugs.” Holly replied: “Aww . . .  what a lovely thing to say . . .  love you Lemon.”

3 May 09:31 • The Scottish Sun • https://www.thescottishsun.co.uk/tvandshowbiz/5556752/holly-willoughby-keith-lemon-quits-celebrity-juice/
Rating: 0.30
Celebrity Juice: Keith Lemon shares hilarious Holly Willoughby video as This Morning presenter 'quits' series

Holly Willoughby has reportedly quit Celebrity Juice after 12 years. The This Morning presenter has been a panellist on the ITV2 series since it began in 2008, but is said to be stepping down to spend more time with her family. Willoughby follows Fearne Cotton, who quit the show in December 2018. Cotton’s replacement, Paddy McGuinness, left after one series before Spice Girl Mel B took over. It’s unknown who could replace Willoughby. A number of episodes recorded in lockdown are expected be her last appearance on the series, which is presented by Keith Lemon. “Holly has absolutely loved her time on the show – it’s been a huge part of her life, and has really helped to expand her fanbase over the years,” a source told The Sun on Sunday. “But she feels now is the right time to bow out and wants to free up a bit more of her busy schedule to spend with her family.” Ahead of the reports, Lemon shared a video of Willoughby on Instagram, in which he looks shocked as she shouts the word “f***” at the screen. He captioned it: “Love this woman. What an incredible sport. Always willing to get her hands dirty and join in. One of the boys but all woman. Super rad! Super nice! My mate! I salute all your wonderfulness. Massive hugs.” Willoughby responded: “Aww... what a lovely thing to say... love you Lemon.” The Independent has contacted a representative of Willoughby for comment.

3 May 08:15 • The Independent • https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/tv/news/holly-willoughby-quits-celebrity-juice-keith-lemon-this-morning-itv2-instagram-a9496151.html?utm_medium=Social&utm_source=Twitter
Rating: 2.71
Holly Willoughby QUITS Celebrity Juice 12 years after ITV panel show helped make her a household name

Holly Willoughby has quit ITV’s Celebrity Juice – the show that helped make her a household name – after 12 years. The presenter will end her reign as a team captain on the award-winning panel show at the end of the current series. Insiders say the decision comes as a blow to programming chiefs, who have long relied on her star quality to attract viewers. Although 39-year-old Miss Willoughby had worked in television for several years before Celebrity Juice, landing the role on the show in 2008 helped make her TV hot property. She joined This Morning a year later and still hosts the show with Phillip Schofield. Celebrity Juice is also where the term ‘Holly Willoughbooby’ was coined to described her curvaceous figure. Her resignation comes shortly after her husband Dan Baldwin – one of Celebrity Juice’s creators – stopped producing the ITV2 show.  The mother of three’s departure now throws the future of the series into doubt after its host Keith Lemon, the comic alter-ego of Leigh Francis, said it would be over if she quit.  A friend of Miss Willoughby told The Mail on Sunday: ‘She absolutely loves being on the show, she has loved it but she felt it was time now.  'She wants to spend more time with her family, filming Celebrity Juice takes up an evening that she could be spending with her family. ‘She is, after all, one of the busiest women in showbiz.’ Yesterday, Francis paid tribute to Miss Willoughby on Instagram under his guise as Keith Lemon, saying: ‘Love this woman. What an incredible sport. Always willing to get her hands dirty and join in. One of the boys but all woman.’ A spokesman for Miss Willoughby last night declined to comment. It is believed the star will make an announcement on Sunday May 3.

Rating: 4.11
Nicola Mclean dishes the dirt on hellish stars during I'm a Celeb stint

Nicola Mclean has told how former I'm A Celeb 2008 camp mate David Van Day wound her up on the show and was an "absolute t***". The former glamour model, 38, invited fans to take part in a Q & A session on her Instagram stories. When asked who was her most favourite and least contestant on the eighth series of the show Nicola told how former 80s pop star, 63, infuriated her. She said: "My least favourite was David Van Day because he was an absolute t***. Literally his sole purpose was to p*** everyone off. it worked good for him but oh my god it was hell to live with." David Van Day has been approached by Mirror Online for comment. Nicola invited her fans to ask her questions to 'give her some entertainment during self-isolation'. She said: "Entertain me guys, ask me some advice, tell me some outrageous stories, ask me a question, anything you want." When one fan asked how is she coping with lockdown, Nicola said 'she was doing alright now, but took her a while to get used to it'. Another fan asked if she would ever get a bum job? Nicola replied: "No I hate them, I hate big bums I want to look straight up and down with big boobs." Nicola claimed in November 2017 that David, who rose to fame in the duo Dollar, made sexual advances towards her on camera. Responding to the comments, David Van Day's wife, Sue Moxley, told MailOnline : "This was all a bit of harmless fun for TV. It was before I met David nine years ago. I don't know why this is being brought up now. She hasn't been in the press much recently. "I though Nicola and I were friends. It would have been nice if she gave me the heads up. We've actually all posed together as a group at a red carpet event since the programme aired and everything was fine and friendly." Nicola is married to footballer Tom Williams, and the couple have two sons, Rocky and Striker. Nicola finished sixth I'm A Celebrity... and also appeared in CelebrityBig Brother

2 May 12:51 • mirror • https://www.mirror.co.uk/3am/celebrity-news/nicola-mclean-dishes-dirt-hellish-21962698
Rating: 2.39
Nicola Mclean dishes the dirt on hellish stars during I'm a Celeb stint

Nicola Mclean has told how former I'm A Celeb 2008 camp mate David Van Day wound her up on the show and was an "absolute t***". The former glamour model, 38, invited fans to take part in a Q & A session on her Instagram stories. When asked who was her most favourite and least contestant on the eighth series of the show Nicola told how former 80s pop star, 63, infuriated her. She said: "My least favourite was David Van Day because he was an absolute t***. Literally his sole purpose was to p*** everyone off. it worked good for him but oh my god it was hell to live with." David Van Day has been approached by Mirror Online for comment. Nicola invited her fans to ask her questions to 'give her some entertainment during self-isolation'. She said: "Entertain me guys, ask me some advice, tell me some outrageous stories, ask me a question, anything you want." When one fan asked how is she coping with lockdown, Nicola said 'she was doing alright now, but took her a while to get used to it'. Another fan asked if she would ever get a bum job? Nicola replied: "No I hate them, I hate big bums I want to look straight up and down with big boobs." Nicola claimed in November 2017 that David, who rose to fame in the duo Dollar, made sexual advances towards her on camera. Responding to the comments, David Van Day's wife, Sue Moxley, told MailOnline : "This was all a bit of harmless fun for TV. It was before I met David nine years ago. I don't know why this is being brought up now. She hasn't been in the press much recently. "I though Nicola and I were friends. It would have been nice if she gave me the heads up. We've actually all posed together as a group at a red carpet event since the programme aired and everything was fine and friendly." Nicola is married to footballer Tom Williams, and the couple have two sons, Rocky and Striker. Nicola finished sixth I'm A Celebrity... and also appeared in CelebrityBig Brother

Lucy Mecklenburgh breastfeeds baby Roman as Ryan Thomas makes her breakfast in bed

Lucy Mecklenburgh breastfeeds baby Roman as Ryan Thomas makes her breakfast in bed

LUCY Mecklenburgh shared an adorable snap of her breastfeeding baby son Roman today as fiancé Ryan Thomas treated her to breakfast in bed. Cradling her son in her arms, makeup Lucy smiled while sitting with banana pancakes on her lap. She shared the pic on Instagram and wrote: "HAPPY SUNDAY!! Roman’s breakfast first then tired Mummas." Her followers praised Ryan for rustling up brekkie, with one writing: "You are spoilt by all these lovely breakfasts! I was lucky if I got a cup of tea!!!! 😘😘😘." The actor recently hailed Lucy a “supermum” after their first baby together was born in isolation. The Manchester-born star admitted they have found it challenging since son Roman’s arrival last month as they haven’t been able to call on family for support. Normally Ryan, 35, would be celebrating the new addition with his brothers — former Emmerdale actor Adam, 31, and his twin, Love Island’s Scott — and their parents Dougie James and Gail Waring. But the pandemic has forced Ryan and ex-Towie regular Lucy, 28, to isolate alone at their home in Essex. It also meant Ryan’s 11-year-old daughter Scarlett — who he co-parents with his ex, Coronation street actress Tina O’Brien, 36 — had to wait a few weeks before meeting her baby brother. Ryan, who played Corrie’s Jason Grimshaw for 16 years until 2016, revealed: “Lucy has been a supermum. “There is no rule book about being a mother and I think it has been a day-to-day challenge and she has dealt with it all amazingly, I’m super proud of her.” Ryan plans to have a big party in Manchester with his family as soon as the Government advises it is safe to do so. He said: “It’s been difficult having the new baby and not being with the boys, it’s just not a normal situation. “The first thing we do when our kids are born is show them off to the brothers. But we’ve been keeping touch and FaceTime a lot. “My daughter is sharing her time between me and her mum. She’s gone home today and then she’ll be back next week or the week after.” Ryan joked that he wants to recreate the iconic scene from Disney’s Lion King when monkey Rafiki presents newborn Simba to the Pride Rock animals. He said: “Hopefully this all dies down and I can drive him home to Manchester and give him the whole Lion King experience.” Lucy told fans on Instagram that Ryan is proving himself to be a proactive dad, mucking in with night feeds and when she is busy running her fitness and nutrition website. She met Ryan three years ago, when they both appeared on Channel 4’s Celebrity Island With Bear Grylls. Lucy said of motherhood: “I’m good. Some days are hard, but Ryan has been so supportive and hands-on it’s helped me so much. “It’s not always easy getting him to sleep but white noise is a lifesaver.” The birth came after Ryan took to social media to describe the “fear and loneliness” of bringing a baby into the world while in lockdown. It inspired the kind-hearted actor to offer nappies, babygrows and formula to parents who are struggling financially. We pay for videos too. Click here to upload yours.

3 May 11:05 • The Sun • https://www.thesun.co.uk/tvandshowbiz/11537756/lucy-mecklenburgh-breastfeeds-baby-roman/
Rating: 2.72
Lucy Mecklenburgh breastfeeds baby Roman with breakfast in bed

Lucy Mecklenburgh had a perfectly lazy Sunday morning as she breastfed her baby boy Roman before devouring breakfast in bed.  The former Towie star gave her social media followers a glimpse into her new morning routine after she and fiance Ryan Thomas welcomed their son Roman two months ago.  And it’s looking a little different these days with feeding Roman obviously the priority first thing on a Sunday morning.  Lucy, 28, shared a photo of herself smiling at the camera while breastfeeding her baby boy with a breakfast tray in front of her.  It looks as though Ryan, 35, prepared the most deliciously sweet brekkie including banana pancakes drizzled with chocolate syrup and a cup of coffee in a mug with ‘mummy’ on it.  ‘HAPPY SUNDAY!! Roman’s breakfast first then tired Mummas 🥞 💤 #stayhome #staysafe #breakfastinbed #mumlife #nomakeup #pancakes,’ Lucy captioned the image.  It comes after Lucy shared her reservations about Roman getting his first set of injections.  ‘Romans immunisations are very soon.. Also both our post natal checks,’ she explained.  ‘And I’m not gonna lie I feel anxious. I feel like we have been isolating for so long in our safe bubble I don’t want him to be near anyone. or in pain from the [injection emoji].  ‘This has made me feel a little better! I also realise they are super important!!’  Lucy and Ryan also spent some quality time with the former Coronation Street actor’s daughter Scarlett, with the family grabbing some fresh air amid lockdown with baby Roman strapped to Lucy’s chest in a carrier.  ‘Love it when I’ve got all my squad together,’ Ryan said alongside the cute family selfie.  The family are finally reunited after Scarlett had to wait a couple of weeks to meet baby Roman to avoid possibly exposing the newborn to coronavirus.  ‘Thank God for technology! I’m finding it really tough being away from my family and sad this is how my daughter met her baby brother,’ Ryan told his social media followers at the time. ‘To any other broken families I feel your pain and it’s killing me being apart from my daughter and family for so long, especially at this special time. ‘BUT we all need to take social isolation and social distancing seriously and it’s a sacrifice we have to make to save lives.’  Got a showbiz story? Lucy Mecklenburgh breastfeeds son Roman before tucking in to breakfast in bed

Television star Lucy Mecklenburgh has been snapped breastfeeding her baby son before breakfast in bed today. The former The Only Way Is Essex star, 28, gave birth to son Roman in March with her fiancé Ryan Thomas. Lucy became engaged to the former Coronation Street actor in June last year after they began dating in 2017. Ryan already has a daughter named Scarlett with his former Corrie co-star Tina O'Brien. Now, Lucy has posted an image of her ideal Sunday morning - breastfeeding adorable Roman and getting breakfast served to her in bed by his daddy Ryan. Sharing the delightful image with her Instagram followers, Lucy looks gorgeous and is a glowing new mother accompanied by some yummy-looking pancakes. She captioned the image: "HAPPY SUNDAY!! Roman’s breakfast first then tired Mummas' #stayhome #staysafe #breakfastinbed #mumlife #nomakeup #pancakes" Her openness with the natural routine of breastfeeding was praised by her fans in the comments section. One of Lucy's followers replied to the post: "Love how open you’re being with motherhood and breastfeeding." Another joked: "The art of picking at your food when babe is feeding. "Did you even breastfeed if you didn’t end up with crumbs on your babe's head?" A different fan of Lucy's commented: "Awwww love this! You’re doing amazingly mama!" Sadly, Ryan is facing time away from his brothers Adam and Scott due to the coronavirus pandemic. He recently revealed on This Morning: "The toughest thing of all is my brothers haven't even met my son yet and I can't wait..." We're sure they'll love him when they meet him! Stacey Solomon films herself while sitting on the toilet

Celebrity mum Stacey Solomon has filmed herself sitting on the toilet after being rudely interrupted by her son Rex. Stacey, 30, was trying to take a moment to herself when her 11-month-old baby barged in to say hello. In scenes familiar to parents everywhere, the Loose Women star captured the funny moment on camera before sharing it online. Read more: Kym Marsh celebrates grandson Teddy's first birthday Stacey's legs can be seen as she asks: "Can I go to the toilet please? Can I? Can I go to the toilet in peace?" The mum-of-three also captioned her Instagram stories post: "When you don't shut the toilet door properly. "Haven't finished a poo since [I] became a mum in 2008." Stacey, who welcomed Rex into the world with long-term boyfriend Joe Swash in May 2019, is loved for her honesty about parenting. The star is also mum to Zachery and Leighton from previous relationships and she isn't shy about documenting her motherhood journey online. Following the toilet incident, Stacey revealed that she was having quite a day with Rex. In another clip, the star managed to film herself as she held the tot in one arm and peeled potatoes with her other hand. She admitted; "He has decided against the morning nap and also does not want to be put down...at all!" Breaking into Blue's hit song One Love, Stacey sang: "It's okay. I'll just have to do everything with...one hand, for the mother's cry, one hand, for the times we cry!" Meanwhile, on Saturday night (May 2, 2020), Stacey experienced a dramatic near miss thanks to Joe, 38. The Dancing On Ice 2020 winner convinced Stacey to perform a move he had learned on the ITV show...and almost dropped her! As one of her older sons filmed, Stacey said: "I don't want to do it, give me my phone back. "No, I'm not going backwards, no, what the hell?! What the hell, Joe?!" Stacey was then seen yelping as Joe tried, and failed, to elegantly hoist her onto his shoulder. She then screamed: "How did you win this, Joe? I'll dismount the other way! No, Joe, no!" Read more: Louis Theroux chops off tip of his finger while making pancakes Thankfully Stacey made it back down to the ground in one piece...and all was forgiven within a few hours. The couple were snapped cuddled up together with their pet dog before heading to bed. Phew! Rating: 0.30
Hoda Kotb Shares An Adorable Instagram Photo Of Her Daughter’s Ice Cream Party

May 2, 2020 Helen Storms Hoda Kotb and her daughters are making the most of quarantine. The Today Show’sHoda Kotb and her two young daughters are making the most of quarantine with an ice cream party. In an adorable Instagram photo that 55-year-old Kotb shared on Saturday, her 3-year-old daughter Haley Joy can be seen munching on an ice cream cone. Kotb stood outside of her family’s New York city home as she snapped a photo of her daughter through an open window. Haley stood inside smiling up at her mother, gripping a half eaten cone in one hand with ice cream and sprinkles all over her mouth. She wore purple glasses and a pink Sesame Street t-shirt. Behind Haley was a small table with what appears to be a child’s homemade ice cream machine on top. It included everything she needed to make the perfect cone, including ice cream scoops and a glass dish with colorful sprinkles. While the 3-year-old was not likely actually selling her cones, she had made it look like a mini ice cream stand. With the help of her mother she drew pictures of ice cream cones and hearts on colorful construction paper which were taped up on the window frame. One sign read the cones were a mere $.10 while another cheerful looking pink sign read “Haley and Hope’s Ice Cream Party.” Even though 1-year-old Hope was not in the photo, it was clear she had been included in the fun. Hoda Kotb’s followers loved the sweet photo and it soon racked up over 33,000 likes in just an hour. Kotb has a whopping 1.6 million followers on the platform overall. Many of her fans took to the comment section to compliment her on the sweet photo, some saying they liked her creative idea and might try it out with their own children. “It looks like the staff there is eating all the goodies!!” one person joked. “What an adorable and happy child!” another person gushed. “I’ll bet any day with Hope and Haley is a fun party day,” one fan wrote. One person jokingly pointed out in the midst of all that is going on in the world, little Haley might want to consider raising the price of her ice cream a little bit. “Up it to $.25 it’s 2020,” they wrote. As The Inquisitr previously reported, the coronavirus pandemic has caused Kotb and her fiance Joel Schiffman to discuss postponing their wedding. They had hoped for a simple beach wedding over the summer but are considering putting things on hold for now to be safe.

3 May 00:51 • The Inquisitr • https://www.inquisitr.com/6031467/hoda-kotb-ice-cream-party/?utm_source=feedburner&utm_medium=feed&utm_campaign=Feed%3A+google%2FyDYq+%28The+Inquisitr+-+News%29

Entertainment
Hollywood artist teams up with Qatar-based sister to tutor Arabic-speaking kids during pandemic

3 May 16:55 • 6 articles
Weight: 1.57
Importance: 1.57
Age penalty: 1.00
Best date: 3 May 16:55
Average US: 7.101666666666667
Weighted average US: 5.529979788584559
Average GB: 0.13
Weighted average GB: 0.1620531291955404
Average IN: 6.7749999999999995
Weighted average IN: 4.948442907941965

Hollywood artist teams up with Qatar-based sister to tutor Arabic-speaking kids during pandemic

Los Angeles: It was during a phone conversation with her sister back in Qatar that the idea clicked for Hollywood animation artist Reem Ali Adeeb. Like other regions across the world, young children in the Middle East were confined at home because of the COVID-19 pandemic, but there was not nearly enough original content online in Arabic to keep them entertained, such as fun tutorials and other activities. So Ali Adeeb, a Syrian-born animation artist who works at Warner Bros. Entertainment in Los Angeles, and her sister Sandi, a university lecturer of pharmaceutics in Qatar, decided to take matters into their own hands. The pair set up "Susupreemo," a YouTube channel designed to help Arabic-speaking kids -- and their stressed-out parents -- weather the coronavirus lockdowns through basic tutorials on drawing, making origami or simply reading children's books, all in Arabic. "The idea is to create videos to engage the kids," said Ali Adeeb, who at Warner Bros. has worked on children's shows including "Green Eggs and Ham," a Netflix animated series based on the Dr. Seuss classic. "There's tons of content on the web in English for kids but there is not enough original content in Arabic," added the 34-year-old who is now working from home on the second season of the Netflix show. "So the aim is to make their screen time interactive and inspiring by drawing with them, reading them a story or doing crafts." Ali Adeeb said her sister's 7-year-old son Omar has even joined in the fun, offering origami tutorials to his peers. "He's been the best. He's done the most among us with three videos recorded already," she said. Ali Adeeb herself is using some of the characters from "Green Eggs and Ham," notably Chickeraffe, a chicken/giraffe hybrid, to draw young viewers into her world. Sandi for her part keeps her young audience focused and allows their imagination to travel by reading them children's books. "I thought I would read for kids during a time where buying or lending a book is very challenging, especially for some disadvantaged kids in some Arab countries," she told AFP in an email. "I started with a book suitable for children aged 3 to 6 years old and now I am selecting more books that can engage the kids for longer periods," she added. A new reality The response, so far, has been overwhelmingly positive with children enthusiastically sharing their drawings via email and parents thankful for the opportunity to be able to hold work meetings online without being interrupted or just have some time for themselves. In a region often wracked by war, and where children faced a harsh reality even before the pandemic, experts say such tutorials offer kids a reprieve whether in the comfort of their homes or even in refugee camps. "Nowadays, children worldwide are confined in their homes and children in the Middle East are no exception," said Annamaria Laurini, the former head of UNICEF in Lebanon. "Suddenly their own world has disappeared -- no more school, no more play with their friends and no more human interactions except with their family," she added. "It's a lonely reality that makes it difficult to dream, that confines their imagination to the walls of their room -- if they are so lucky to have one." Soha Bsat Boustani, a UNICEF consultant based in Beirut, said the YouTube tutorials are much needed in a region where such material in Arabic for children is lagging in terms of creativity and innovation. "And so, initiatives like 'Susupreemo' can only be seen in a positive light as it gives children a healthy way out of confinement and a sense of normalcy." So far Ali Adeeb, her sister and nephew have produced seven videos and they hope to continue with their project even after the pandemic. "I'm thinking now of teaching kids how to draw popular cartoon characters ... and I'm hoping to open this space for other artists," she said. "I have a friend who is a dancer and I would love for her to teach kids how to dance. "There's a lot more we can do." Read More'Keep going': Syrian refugees use war resilience to confront virus It is not the first catastrophe they have faced. But while today's global pandemic bears no resemblance to Syria's almost decade-long civil war, some refugees believe their experience of violence and exile helps them deal with the anxiety sparked by the novel coronavirus. Read MoreA Minute With: Tim Gunn on pajamas and post-quarantine fashion Even Tim Gunn, the immaculately dressed fashion mentor from "Project Runway" and Amazon's new competition show "Making the Cut," is finding it hard to get out of his pajamas these days. Read MoreMisery of Italy's migrants grows not from virus but lockdown They are known as "the invisibles": Undocumented African migrants who, even before the coronavirus outbreak plunged Italy into crisis, barely scraped by as day laborers, prostitutes, freelance hairdressers and seasonal farm hands.

3 May 16:55 • The Peninsula • https://thepeninsulaqatar.com/article/03/05/2020/Hollywood-artist-teams-up-with-Qatar-based-sister-to-tutor-Arabic-speaking-kids-during-pandemic
Rating: 3.14
Hollywood artist tutors Arabic-speaking kids during pandemic

It was during a phone conversation with her sister back in Qatar that the idea clicked for Hollywood animation artist Reem Ali Adeeb. Like other regions across the world, young children in the Middle East were confined at home because of the COVID-19 pandemic, but there was not nearly enough original content online in Arabic to keep them entertained, such as fun tutorials and other activities. So Ali Adeeb, a Syrian-born animation artist who works at Warner Bros. Entertainment in Los Angeles, and her sister Sandi, a university lecturer of pharmaceutics in Qatar, decided to take matters into their own hands. The pair set up "Susupreemo," a YouTube channel designed to help Arabic-speaking kids—and their stressed-out parents—weather the coronavirus lockdowns through basic tutorials on drawing, making origami or simply reading children's books, all in Arabic. "The idea is to create videos to engage the kids," said Ali Adeeb, who at Warner Bros. has worked on children's shows including "Green Eggs and Ham," a Netflix animated series based on the Dr. Seuss classic. "There's tons of content on the web in English for kids but there is not enough original content in Arabic," added the 34-year-old who is now working from home on the second season of the Netflix show. "So the aim is to make their screen time interactive and inspiring by drawing with them, reading them a story or doing crafts." Ali Adeeb said her sister's 7-year-old son Omar has even joined in the fun, offering origami tutorials to his peers. "He's been the best. He's done the most among us with three videos recorded already," she said. Ali Adeeb herself is using some of the characters from "Green Eggs and Ham," notably Chickeraffe, a chicken/giraffe hybrid, to draw young viewers into her world. Sandi for her part keeps her young audience focused and allows their imagination to travel by reading them children's books. "I thought I would read for kids during a time where buying or lending a book is very challenging, especially for some disadvantaged kids in some Arab countries," she told AFP in an email. "I started with a book suitable for children aged 3 to 6 years old and now I am selecting more books that can engage the kids for longer periods," she added. A new reality The response, so far, has been overwhelmingly positive with children enthusiastically sharing their drawings via email and parents thankful for the opportunity to be able to hold work meetings online without being interrupted or just have some time for themselves. In a region often wracked by war, and where children faced a harsh reality even before the pandemic, experts say such tutorials offer kids a reprieve whether in the comfort of their homes or even in refugee camps. "Nowadays, children worldwide are confined in their homes, and children in the Middle East are no exception," said Annamaria Laurini, the former head of UNICEF in Lebanon. "Suddenly their own world has disappeared -- no more school, no more play with their friends and no more human interactions except with their family," she added. "It's a lonely reality that makes it difficult to dream, that confines their imagination to the walls of their room -- if they are so lucky to have one." Soha Bsat Boustani, a UNICEF consultant based in Beirut, said the YouTube tutorials are much needed in a region where such material in Arabic for children is lagging in terms of creativity and innovation. "And so, initiatives like 'Susupreemo' can only be seen in a positive light as it gives children a healthy way out of confinement and a sense of normalcy."   So far Ali Adeeb, her sister and nephew have produced seven videos and they hope to continue with their project even after the pandemic. "I'm thinking now of teaching kids how to draw popular cartoon characters ... and I'm hoping to open this space for other artists," she said. "I have a friend who is a dancer and I would love for her to teach kids how to dance. "There's a lot more we can do."

3 May 10:00 • manilastandard.net • https://manilastandard.net/showbitz/celebrity-profiles/322883/hollywood-artist-tutors-arabic-speaking-kids-during-pandemic.html
Rating: 0.30
What We Are Reading Today: The Inevitability of Tragedy by Barry Gewen

LOS ANGELES: It was during a phone conversation with her sister that the idea clicked for Hollywood animation artist Reem Ali Adeeb. Like other regions across the world, young children in the Middle East were confined at home because of the COVID-19 pandemic, but there was not nearly enough original content online in Arabic to keep them entertained, such as fun tutorials and other activities. So Ali Adeeb, a Syrian-born animation artist who works at Warner Bros. Entertainment in Los Angeles, and her sister Sandi, a university lecturer of pharmaceutics, decided to take matters into their own hands. The pair set up "Susupreemo," a YouTube channel designed to help Arabic-speaking kids – and their stressed-out parents – weather the coronavirus lockdowns through basic tutorials on drawing, making origami or simply reading children's books, all in Arabic. "The idea is to create videos to engage the kids," said Ali Adeeb, who at Warner Bros. has worked on children's shows including "Green Eggs and Ham," a Netflix animated series based on the Dr. Seuss classic. The aritist is developing online tutorials in Arabic for children about art, including drawing and reading. (AFP) "There's tons of content on the web in English for kids but there is not enough original content in Arabic," added the 34-year-old who is now working from home on the second season of the Netflix show. "So the aim is to make their screen time interactive and inspiring by drawing with them, reading them a story or doing crafts." Ali Adeeb said her sister's 7-year-old son Omar has even joined in the fun, offering origami tutorials to his peers. "He's been the best. He's done the most among us with three videos recorded already," she said. Ali Adeeb herself is using some of the characters from "Green Eggs and Ham," notably Chickeraffe, a chicken/giraffe hybrid, to draw young viewers into her world. Sandi for her part keeps her young audience focused and allows their imagination to travel by reading them children's books. "I thought I would read for kids during a time where buying or lending a book is very challenging, especially for some disadvantaged kids in some Arab countries," she told AFP in an email. "I started with a book suitable for children aged 3 to 6 years old and now I am selecting more books that can engage the kids for longer periods," she added. The response, so far, has been overwhelmingly positive with children enthusiastically sharing their drawings via email and parents thankful for the opportunity to be able to hold work meetings online without being interrupted or just have some time for themselves. In a region often wracked by war, and where children faced a harsh reality even before the pandemic, experts say such tutorials offer kids a reprieve whether in the comfort of their homes or even in refugee camps. "Nowadays, children worldwide are confined in their homes and children in the Middle East are no exception," said Annamaria Laurini, the former head of UNICEF in Lebanon. "Suddenly their own world has disappeared – no more school, no more play with their friends and no more human interactions except with their family," she added. "It's a lonely reality that makes it difficult to dream, that confines their imagination to the walls of their room – if they are so lucky to have one." Soha Bsat Boustani, a UNICEF consultant based in Beirut, said the YouTube tutorials are much needed in a region where such material in Arabic for children is lagging in terms of creativity and innovation. "And so, initiatives like 'Susupreemo' can only be seen in a positive light as it gives children a healthy way out of confinement and a sense of normalcy." So far Ali Adeeb, her sister and nephew have produced seven videos and they hope to continue with their project even after the pandemic. "I'm thinking now of teaching kids how to draw popular cartoon characters ... and I'm hoping to open this space for other artists," she said. "I have a friend who is a dancer and I would love for her to teach kids how to dance."There's a lot more we can do."

3 May 07:00 • Arab News • https://www.arabnews.com/node/1668876/lifestyle
Rating: 1.72
Hollywood artist tutors Arabic-speaking kids during pandemic

Los Angeles, United States | AFP |  It was during a phone conversation with her sister back in Qatar that the idea clicked for Hollywood animation artist Reem Ali Adeeb. Like other regions across the world, young children in the Middle East were confined at home because of the COVID-19 pandemic, but there was not nearly enough original content online in Arabic to keep them entertained, such as fun tutorials and other activities. So Ali Adeeb, a Syrian-born animation artist who works at Warner Bros. Entertainment in Los Angeles, and her sister Sandi, a university lecturer of pharmaceutics in Qatar, decided to take matters into their own hands. The pair set up “Susupreemo,” a YouTube channel designed to help Arabic-speaking kids — and their stressed-out parents — weather the coronavirus lockdowns through basic tutorials on drawing, making origami or simply reading children’s books, all in Arabic. “The idea is to create videos to engage the kids,” said Ali Adeeb, who at Warner Bros. has worked on children’s shows including “Green Eggs and Ham,” a Netflix animated series based on the Dr. Seuss classic. “There’s tons of content on the web in English for kids but there is not enough original content in Arabic,”  added the 34-year-old who is now working from home on the second season of the Netflix show. “So the aim is to make their screen time interactive and inspiring by drawing with them, reading them a story or doing crafts.” Ali Adeeb said her sister’s 7-year-old son Omar has even joined in the fun, offering origami tutorials to his peers. “He’s been the best. He’s done the most among us with three videos recorded already,” she said. Ali Adeeb herself is using some of the characters from “Green Eggs and Ham,” notably Chickeraffe, a chicken/giraffe hybrid, to draw young viewers into her world. Sandi for her part keeps her young audience focused and allows their imagination to travel by reading them children’s books. “I thought I would read for kids during a time where buying or lending a book is very challenging, especially for some disadvantaged kids in some Arab countries,” she told AFP in an email. “I started with a book suitable for children aged 3 to 6 years old and now I am selecting more books that can engage the kids for longer periods,” she added. – A new reality – The response, so far, has been overwhelmingly positive with children enthusiastically sharing their drawings via email and parents thankful for the opportunity to be able to hold work meetings online without being interrupted or just have some time for themselves. In a region often wracked by war, and where children faced a harsh reality even before the pandemic, experts say such tutorials offer kids a reprieve whether in the comfort of their homes or even in refugee camps. “Nowadays, children worldwide are confined in their homes and  children in the Middle East are no exception,” said Annamaria Laurini, the former head of UNICEF in Lebanon. “Suddenly their own world has disappeared — no more school, no more play with their friends and no more human interactions except with their family,” she added. “It’s a lonely reality that makes it difficult to dream, that confines their imagination to the walls of their room — if they are so lucky to have one.” Soha Bsat Boustani, a UNICEF consultant based in Beirut, said the YouTube tutorials are much needed in a region where such material in Arabic for children is lagging in terms of creativity and innovation. “And so, initiatives like ‘Susupreemo’ can only be seen in a positive light as it gives children a healthy way out of confinement and a sense of normalcy.” So far Ali Adeeb, her sister and nephew have produced seven videos and they hope to continue with their project even after the pandemic. “I’m thinking now of teaching kids how to draw popular cartoon characters … and I’m hoping to open this space for other artists,” she said. “I have a friend who is a dancer and I would love for her to teach kids how to dance. “There’s a lot more we can do.”   Share on: WhatsApp

3 May 05:30 • The Independent Uganda: • https://www.independent.co.ug/hollywood-artist-tutors-arabic-speaking-kids-during-pandemic/
Rating: 0.30
Hollywood artist tutors Arabic-speaking kids during pandemic

LOS ANGELES, USA – It was during a phone conversation with her sister back in Qatar that the idea clicked for Hollywood animation artist Reem Ali Adeeb. Like other regions across the world, young children in the Middle East were confined at home because of the COVID-19 pandemic, but there was not nearly enough original content online in Arabic to keep them entertained, such as fun tutorials and other activities. So Ali Adeeb, a Syrian-born animation artist who works at Warner Bros. Entertainment in Los Angeles, and her sister Sandi, a university lecturer of pharmaceutics in Qatar, decided to take matters into their own hands. The pair set up "Susupreemo," a YouTube channel designed to help Arabic-speaking kids – and their stressed-out parents – weather the coronavirus lockdowns through basic tutorials on drawing, making origami or simply reading children's books, all in Arabic. "The idea is to create videos to engage the kids," said Ali Adeeb, who at Warner Bros. has worked on children's shows including Green Eggs and Ham, a Netflix animated series based on the Dr. Seuss classic. "There's tons of content on the web in English for kids but there is not enough original content in Arabic," added the 34-year-old who is now working from home on the second season of the Netflix show. "So the aim is to make their screen time interactive and inspiring by drawing with them, reading them a story or doing crafts." Ali Adeeb said her sister's 7-year-old son Omar has even joined in the fun, offering origami tutorials to his peers. "He's been the best. He's done the most among us with three videos recorded already," she said. Ali Adeeb herself is using some of the characters from Green Eggs and Ham, notably Chickeraffe, a chicken/giraffe hybrid, to draw young viewers into her world. Sandi for her part keeps her young audience focused and allows their imagination to travel by reading them children's books. "I thought I would read for kids during a time where buying or lending a book is very challenging, especially for some disadvantaged kids in some Arab countries," she told AFP in an email. "I started with a book suitable for children aged 3 to 6 years old and now I am selecting more books that can engage the kids for longer periods," she added. A new reality The response, so far, has been overwhelmingly positive with children enthusiastically sharing their drawings via email and parents thankful for the opportunity to be able to hold work meetings online without being interrupted or just have some time for themselves. In a region often wracked by war, and where children faced a harsh reality even before the pandemic, experts say such tutorials offer kids a reprieve whether in the comfort of their homes or even in refugee camps. "Nowadays, children worldwide are confined in their homes and children in the Middle East are no exception," said Annamaria Laurini, the former head of UNICEF in Lebanon. "Suddenly their own world has disappeared – no more school, no more play with their friends and no more human interactions except with their family," she added. "It's a lonely reality that makes it difficult to dream, that confines their imagination to the walls of their room – if they are so lucky to have one." Soha Bsat Boustani, a UNICEF consultant based in Beirut, said the YouTube tutorials are much needed in a region where such material in Arabic for children is lagging in terms of creativity and innovation. "And so, initiatives like 'Susupreemo' can only be seen in a positive light as it gives children a healthy way out of confinement and a sense of normalcy." So far Ali Adeeb, her sister and nephew have produced seven videos and they hope to continue with their project even after the pandemic. "I'm thinking now of teaching kids how to draw popular cartoon characters ... and I'm hoping to open this space for other artists," she said. "I have a friend who is a dancer and I would love for her to teach kids how to dance. "There's a lot more we can do." – Rappler.com

3 May 03:12 • Rappler • https://www.rappler.com/entertainment/news/259761-hollywood-artist-tutors-arabic-speaking-kids-coronavrius
Rating: 1.64
Hollywood artist tutors Arabic-speaking kids during pandemic

It was during a phone conversation with her sister back in Qatar that the idea clicked for Hollywood animation artist Reem Ali Adeeb. Like other regions across the world, young children in the Middle East were confined at home because of the COVID-19 pandemic, but there was not nearly enough original content online in Arabic to keep them entertained, such as fun tutorials and other activities. So Ali Adeeb, a Syrian-born animation artist who works at Warner Bros. Entertainment in Los Angeles, and her sister Sandi, a university lecturer of pharmaceutics in Qatar, decided to take matters into their own hands. The pair set up "Susupreemo," a YouTube channel designed to help Arabic-speaking kids -- and their stressed-out parents -- weather the coronavirus lockdowns through basic tutorials on drawing, making origami or simply reading children's books, all in Arabic. "The idea is to create videos to engage the kids," said Ali Adeeb, who at Warner Bros. has worked on children's shows including "Green Eggs and Ham," a Netflix animated series based on the Dr. Seuss classic. "There's tons of content on the web in English for kids but there is not enough original content in Arabic," added the 34-year-old who is now working from home on the second season of the Netflix show. "So the aim is to make their screen time interactive and inspiring by drawing with them, reading them a story or doing crafts." Ali Adeeb said her sister's 7-year-old son Omar has even joined in the fun, offering origami tutorials to his peers. "He's been the best. He's done the most among us with three videos recorded already," she said. Ali Adeeb herself is using some of the characters from "Green Eggs and Ham," notably Chickeraffe, a chicken/giraffe hybrid, to draw young viewers into her world. Sandi for her part keeps her young audience focused and allows their imagination to travel by reading them children's books. "I thought I would read for kids during a time where buying or lending a book is very challenging, especially for some disadvantaged kids in some Arab countries," she told AFP in an email. "I started with a book suitable for children aged 3 to 6 years old and now I am selecting more books that can engage the kids for longer periods," she added. - A new reality - The response, so far, has been overwhelmingly positive with children enthusiastically sharing their drawings via email and parents thankful for the opportunity to be able to hold work meetings online without being interrupted or just have some time for themselves. In a region often wracked by war, and where children faced a harsh reality even before the pandemic, experts say such tutorials offer kids a reprieve whether in the comfort of their homes or even in refugee camps. "Nowadays, children worldwide are confined in their homes and children in the Middle East are no exception," said Annamaria Laurini, the former head of UNICEF in Lebanon. "Suddenly their own world has disappeared -- no more school, no more play with their friends and no more human interactions except with their family," she added. "It's a lonely reality that makes it difficult to dream, that confines their imagination to the walls of their room -- if they are so lucky to have one." Soha Bsat Boustani, a UNICEF consultant based in Beirut, said the YouTube tutorials are much needed in a region where such material in Arabic for children is lagging in terms of creativity and innovation. "And so, initiatives like 'Susupreemo' can only be seen in a positive light as it gives children a healthy way out of confinement and a sense of normalcy." So far Ali Adeeb, her sister and nephew have produced seven videos and they hope to continue with their project even after the pandemic. "I'm thinking now of teaching kids how to draw popular cartoon characters ... and I'm hoping to open this space for other artists," she said. "I have a friend who is a dancer and I would love for her to teach kids how to dance. "There's a lot more we can do."
